articles.headline: Prisoner Deal Reopens an Israeli Wound
articles.snippet: The prospect of exchanging one of the country’s most despised prisoners for corpses has raised hackles.
articles.abstract: The prospect of exchanging one of the country’s most despised prisoners for corpses has raised hackles.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAHARIYA, Israel — Israel is a tale of family tragedies lived out within small distances.

articles.headline: Fed Chief Bleak on Economic Outlook
articles.snippet: A sense of gloom gripped Washington as the Federal Reserve chairman warned of the risks of a slowdown.
articles.abstract: A sense of gloom gripped Washington as the Federal Reserve chairman warned of the risks of a slowdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A sense of economic gloom gripped Washington on Tuesday as President Bush urged Americans not to lose faith, the Federal Reserve chairman offered a mostly bleak assessment of the difficulties ahead for the economy, and the administration’s latest effort to help the housing sector faced tough questioning in Congress.

articles.headline: Homes at Risk, More Owners Consider Taking in Boarders
articles.snippet: As mortgage foreclosures continue to rise, owners are opening their homes as a way to make ends meet.
articles.abstract: As mortgage foreclosures continue to rise, owners are opening their homes as a way to make ends meet.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — When Barbara Terry fell behind on her mortgage payments earlier this year, she did the previously unthinkable. Through a local housing organization, she and her daughter, Imani, 9, rented part of their single-family house to a stranger.

articles.headline: A 1913 Law Dies to Better Serve Gay Marriages
articles.snippet: Officials in Massachusetts are considering the economic benefits of allowing same-sex marriages in the state.
articles.abstract: Officials in Massachusetts are considering the economic benefits of allowing same-sex marriages in the state.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Massachusetts may have been the first state to legalize same-sex marriage for its residents, but when California last month invited out-of-state gay and lesbian couples to get married, the potential economic benefits did not go unnoticed here. Now Massachusetts wants to extend the same invitation.
articles.byline: By Pam Belluck and Katie Zezima

articles.headline: With Warning, G.M. Takes Wide Cost Cuts
articles.snippet: G.M. said that it would reduce labor costs for salaried workers by 20 percent and further cut truck production.
articles.abstract: G.M. said that it would reduce labor costs for salaried workers by 20 percent and further cut truck production.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — With concern growing among investors about a possible bankruptcy filing, General Motors on Tuesday announced sweeping cost cuts and other measures to bolster its tenuous cash position.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Unveils Measures to Limit Short-Selling
articles.snippet: Securities regulators plan to issue an emergency rule to limit certain types of short selling in major financial firms, including Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
articles.abstract: Securities regulators plan to issue an emergency rule to limit certain types of short selling in major financial firms, including Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission, under pressure to respond to the tumult in the financial industry, announced emergency measures on Tuesday to curb certain kinds of short-selling that aims at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, as well as Wall Street banks.

articles.headline: Democrats See a Need for Further Economic Stimulus
articles.snippet: President Bush and the Fed chairman called the spending package proposed by Democrats premature.
articles.abstract: President Bush and the Fed chairman called the spending package proposed by Democrats premature.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many economists have concluded that a second dose of government stimulus spending is required to prevent a broad economic unraveling and provide relief to millions of Americans grappling with joblessness, plunging home prices and tight credit.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Seeing Bad Loans, Investors Flee From Bank Shares
articles.snippet: Goaded by bearish analysts, investors seem to be abandoning American banks in droves.
articles.abstract: Goaded by bearish analysts, investors seem to be abandoning American banks in droves.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, the run is on.

articles.headline: The Daily News and The Post Talk Business
articles.snippet: Rupert Murdoch, whose News Corporation owns The New York Post, and Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the owner of The Daily News, are considering the unthinkable: cooperation.
articles.abstract: Rupert Murdoch, whose News Corporation owns The New York Post, and Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the owner of The Daily News, are considering the unthinkable: cooperation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch, whose News Corporation owns The New York Post, and Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the real estate developer and owner of The Daily News, who for years have been bitter tabloid competitors, are considering the unthinkable: cooperation.

articles.headline: Poll Finds Obama Isn’t Closing Divide on Race
articles.snippet: Blacks and whites hold vastly different views of Senator Barack Obama and the state of race relations, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.abstract: Blacks and whites hold vastly different views of Senator Barack Obama and the state of race relations, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans are sharply divided by race heading into the first election in which an African-American will be a major-party presidential nominee, with blacks and whites holding vastly different views of Senator Barack Obama, the state of race relations and how black Americans are treated by society, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.byline: By ADAM NAGOURNEY and MEGAN THEE

articles.headline: Opposition, From Both Parties, Over Bailout Plan
articles.snippet: Some members of Congress criticized the plan to aid Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac as an open-ended request for cash.
articles.abstract: Some members of Congress criticized the plan to aid Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac as an open-ended request for cash.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration’s plan to rescue the nation’s two largest mortgage finance companies ran into sharp criticism in Congress on Tuesday as some lawmakers questioned the open-ended request for money that could be used to help the companies.
articles.byline: By Stephen Labaton and David M. Herszenhorn
